title: 104_hr1307
content:
SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds that the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District and associated historic sites are significant for illustrating the history of the whaling industry in the United States. New Bedford was once the world's whaling capital in the 19th century, with architectural features, archival materials, and museum collections that showcase this period. These historic resources offer opportunities for public enjoyment and education on the economic, social, and environmental impact of the whaling industry. The purposes of this Act are to preserve, protect, and interpret resources within the described areas, collaborate with local organizations to further park purposes, and provide educational opportunities for the American people. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

For the purposes of this Act:
(1) The term "park" refers to the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park established by section 3.
(2) The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 3. NEW BEDFORD WHALING NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park is established to preserve historical districts, structures, and relics in New Bedford, Massachusetts related to whaling and American history. The boundaries of the park are defined by a specific map and include the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District. The Bedford Landing Waterfront Historic District, National Historic Landmark Schooner Ernestina, and specific land areas in New Bedford are listed in the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary may also assist in interpreting and preserving additional sites and relics. The preservation efforts include the southwest corner of the State Pier, Waterfront Park, Rotch-Jones-Duff House and Garden Museum, Wharfinger Building, and Bourne Counting House. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION OF PARK. The park will be administered by the Secretary in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act. The Secretary can enter into cooperative agreements for the preservation and use of the park, with payments subject to conditions to prevent misuse. The Secretary can enter into cooperative agreements for the preservation and use of the park, with payments subject to conditions to prevent misuse. Funds for cooperative agreements and construction projects must adhere to specific matching requirements between Federal and non-Federal sources. The Secretary is authorized to accept donations of money, property, services, or goods from non-Federal sources for the park. Only donations of lands, interests in lands, and improvements within the park can be acquired. Donated funds, property, and services can be accepted to carry out the Act. The Secretary must submit a general management plan for the park within two years of the Act's enactment and implement it promptly. The plan must comply with relevant laws. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary for annual operations and maintenance of the park are authorized to be appropriated, with exceptions for specific purposes such as construction and educational programs for the Schooner Ernestina.
